Fields.DialogueText: Come on, we can all do better than that! Those gulls are flying with more grace than our own VB-6s!
Good day, Enterprise.
And the time it took to get all aircraft aloft! Do you think the Morganas will sit around twiddling their thumbs as we try in vain to find our asses with our hands?
And... oh! Captain! You snuck up on me!
It was hard not to, with all the noise you were making. Trying to bring down crew morale, eh?
What? No, of course not! They just need a bit of encouragement, now and again, from their Belle.

Fields.MenuText: Hah, of course. I was only joking.
It's good you're keeping the crew on their toes.
That hardly sounds like encouragement.

Fields.DialogueText: Hah, right. I knew you understood, Captain.
Thank you! I'm glad to do it.
It's only a bit of ribbing... far more tame than the official reprimands handed down by officers, and far, far more tame than what every seaman hears from their bunkmates.
In any event, you're right. We're not running smoothly at all. The crew is hardly battleworthy. Especially with the transition to Neutrality Fleet mixed crews...
Half the crew are still learning protocols! We need to spend every spare moment on drilling. The few Morgana attacks we've weathered so far have been hardly representative.
There aren't many people I know who get excited at the prospect of drills.
I like to see the squadrons take flight, and hear the roar of my guns. I'm a simple girl, Captain.
Ha! That's fair enough. The drills certainly are needed.
I know nobody aboard likes drills, but the more we drill, the more our crew will become one natural, functioning machine. And it doesn't just build efficiency in combat. It brings us together.
You've convinced me, you've convinced me. I wasn't going to challenge your suggestion anyway.
Ah, Captain, it just feels so good to be able to speak my mind! Speaking of which, there's a blip on the radar to port. I think it's a Morgana.
Damn. I suppose we'll have to see how the crew performs.
Baptism by fire! We can do this, Captain.
@BATTLE
My RDF is picking up a vessel moving toward us like a bat out of hell.
It's most likely a Morgana. There are no Neutrality Fleet vessels in this area aside from those accompanying us.
There she is! Off to port, Captain. Here, take my spyglass.
You've got sharp eyes, Enterprise.
You bet! I ate lots of carrots when I was a girl.
... What?
... Never mind. I don't, really, my eyes aren't great. It's just the Range and Direction Finding equipment. It's quite a handy invention.
I'll say. Do you think we're in a state for a fight?
I don't think we have a choice. Even if that Morgana isn't targeting us specifically, a large target like me would be hard for her to pass up.
You have a point. All hands to stations! I want all squadrons in the air!
@BATTLE
Ha! Excellent job, boys and girls! That Morgana hardly knew what hit her!
We certainly performed better than before, but not perfectly. It will cost to replace those planes the pilots had to ditch.
We're certainly still ironing out the kinks, but we've got a solid foundation. I love my planes, but I love my pilots more. I'm just glad we were able to retrieve them in time.

Fields.MenuText: That's true. Equipment is easier to replace than men.
It's excellent we were able to rescue the pilots, but losing the planes is no small cost.
You shouldn't treat valuable resources like our planes so flippantly.

Fields.DialogueText: Exactly! Not that losing those planes isn't a setback, but things could have gone much worse.
You're right, it isn't. With further drilling and practice, we can reduce the number of ditch landings... but I think we did well, for a crew that is still settling in.
I don't! I'm a resource myself, Captain, I understand the importance of my planes, and I love them, but I would rather have metal casualties than human ones.
Think of this as our shakedown cruise, Captain, for your captaincy and for our new crew.
It's a bit eventful to be called a shakedown cruise.
Like I said before, it's a trial by fire. We have to rise to the challenge.
Rolling home, rolling home, rolling home across the sea, rolling home to dear old Vir-gi-ni-a, rolling home, dear land, to thee!
You're certainly in a sunny mood today.
Who wouldn't be? We're going to make port at my home! Dear old Virginia... Newport News, where I was dreamed up and constructed.
I didn't realize Belles had such attachments to their shipyards.
Love for one's home isn't such a strange emotion, you know! Don't you miss your home?

Fields.MenuText: Every day. Sometimes I wish I was still there, instead of out here on the sea...
I try not to think of it. Nostalgia can't do any good.
The sea is my home, and I wouldn't trade it for any piece of land.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, Captain! I understand. The sooner we beat the Morganas, the sooner you can go home.
I understand. I'm sorry if my excitement was insensitive. I didn't mean to cause you harm.
I understand that! The sea is truly my life. I wouldn't want to stay beached in Newport News.
But it is nice to see that dear old shipyard once in a while... look! You can see it from here! Land ho!
We're just coming in for a few quick adjustments and to onboard some more aircraft. I don't think we'll be at the shipyard for long.
That's fine. It will be good to see it anyway... Look! Captain! To port! There's Morganas heading in our direction. They've got a dreadnought, or something like it...
Give me that glass, please. ... Yes. That doesn't look good.
I'd bet my bottom dollar those dirty bitches want to wreck the shipyard! We've got to stop them.
We're not exactly combat ready...
We've got to protect the shipyard, Captain! Please!
@BATTLE
I hope the Morganas learned a good lesson about not messing with my hometown!
I wouldn't worry about that. It's just...
Captain? Is everything alright?
Hm. For the most part. It's only, we've been formally reprimanded by one of the Neutrality Fleet admirals.
What for? Our stunning victory? Surely not.
I'm afraid so. He disagrees with my methods of captaining an aircraft carrier. He says your fleets of ships and our resources should be focused on providing backup to other ships...
Not throwing ourselves into battle, like we have been doing?
Exactly. He says with your lack of firepower, it's a disaster waiting to happen.
What a load of bull! I may not have the biggest, shiniest artillery in the Fleet, but my aircraft and my pilots are capable of doing far more than a run-of-the-mill battleship!

Fields.MenuText: Calm down, I believe you.
It's not me you have to convince. It's the Neutrality Fleet brass.
He may be right to suggest caution.

Fields.DialogueText: ... Good. I'm sorry, I just know my own potential. I know how much is too much for me!
I know! I'm sorry for snapping at you, Captain. It's just irritating.
Caution is good, but I know I... we... can contribute far more to the war if we're allowed to fight.
What did he want us to do? Sit back and watch the shipyard burn? Over my dead body!
I don't know.
It's frustrating that the brass can be so stuck in their old ways, afraid to let any new strategies be tried. This is an age of change, after all. Us Belles, the Morganas...
The old rules of war certainly don't apply much anymore.
There you are! Why are you hiding down here in storage, Enterprise? I swear I've been around half the ship looking for you.
Shhh! Captain! You'll wake the kittens!
... Kittens?
Look! I think we picked up this little stowaway in Virginia. I guess she was looking for a safe place to raise a family.
I spotted her carrying one up the gangplank, and I've been looking for her since.

Fields.MenuText: They are pretty cute.
At least they'll help keep down the rat population.
Those creatures don't belong onboard.

Fields.DialogueText: Aren't they, though?
Of course! They'll be hardworking members of the crew, Captain, I promise.
Yes they do! I am this ship, and I decree it. Please, Captain, aren't they adorable?
They're sure to be useful to the war effort. Please, can we keep them?
Very well. So long as they pull their weight, and don't become a nuisance.
I'll make sure they're raised to be good cats, Captain.
... Enterprise?
Captain?
Can you... talk to cats? Can Belles talk to cats?
What a ridiculous question! We have bigger things to worry about. My RDF just pinged a Morgana heading towards us.
Fair point. Let's get to the bridge. ... Are you bringing the cats?
Of course not, Cap. I'm going to drop them off in your cabin.
My... cabin...
@BATTLE
Sin is approaching off port, Captain! She's an ugly monstrosity, but she's an aircraft carrier, so I expect she'll have a force of planes similar to ours.
We're not well equipped to repel aircraft.
It's true we don't have much anti-aircraft power onboard, but our aircraft should repel hers just as nicely. Better, even!
@BATTLE
Captain! Captain! Are you hurt? How badly?
Augh... just scraped and bruised. My ears are still ringing from that shell...
Hah, my heart dropped to my boots when I saw it coming! I could feel the vibrations of the impact in my bones...
Where were you? You flickered away at some point...
I go where I'm needed in battle, Captain. Haven't you noticed? One of the gunnery crews needed an extra pair of hands.
I see.
We should get you to sick bay, Cap. You may feel fine, but injuries don't always manifest themselves immediately, especially when the state of shock is possible.
Are you... mothering me? You're... eighteen? Nineteen?
I'm a *Belle.* And you're my captain, and I'm concerned about your wellbeing.

Fields.MenuText: I'm touched by your concern, but I really do feel fine, aside from a few bumps.
There are other people on this ship who merit your concern.
I can take care of myself.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad, but like I said before, I'd prefer if one of the doctors looked over you anyway.
I know. I'm concerned about them too. But you're my captain, and I have to make sure you're well.
I'm not saying you can't! I just... ugh.
Just humor me and visit the sick bay, will you? Please?
Fine.
Captain? What are you doing up here?
Mind if I join you?
... Not at all. Actually, there's something I've been meaning to tell you... or ask you? No, tell you.
What is it?
You know it's okay to be afraid, right?
What?
I'm a little bit afraid most of the time. Especially when it comes to Morganas. The first few fights, I was terrified, and... I still am, on the inside.
... Really?
Shaking in my boots, every battle. But... fear keeps you alive. It's acceptable to be afraid, as long as you do your duty as well.
It's not fitting for a commanding officer, or a Belle, to show fear to the crew, I know, but... we can trust each other, right? This is the sort of thing we can talk about.
Absolutely. We can trust each other.

Fields.MenuText: I am afraid, Enterprise, like you said.
I get nervous sometimes, but I wouldn't call it fear.
I'm not afraid. No Morgana has ever scared me.

Fields.DialogueText: It can seem almost too much to bear sometimes, can't it? We can bear it together, though.
Performance anxiety. I get that too. It runs deeper, but we've all got to push through that.
... Then you're braver than me, Captain, and I salute you.
... Regardless, you're right. These are the sorts of things we can trust with each other. It's strange, the place a Belle holds on a ship.
It is. But us Belles, we're here to help, whether you need a friendly kick, or a helping hand, or a listening ear. So don't be afraid to talk to me, Captain.
I won't be, Enterprise.
Keep it together. Keep it together.
Don't worry about me, Captain. This is nothing!
Yeah. That's all it is.
@BATTLE
The Maine coastline is so beautiful... Sometimes I wish I was a smaller ship, so I could explore more of America.
You couldn't have your fleet of airplanes, then, or your guns.
That's true, hah. It's just a silly desire... One of my predecessors, the first USS Enterprise, was burned inland, on the banks of Lake Champlain. I'd love to see that lake.
That sounds rather grim.
She was the first ship to bear my name... my ancestor, in a way. I have to live up to her legacy, and the legacy of all those who came before me.
I hope you don't follow her legacy too closely. The burning bit, anyway.
She wasn't burned by the enemy... she was burned by her captain and crew, to keep her from falling into enemy hands.
That is grim.
It was necessary, Captain. In a war like that... in most wars... resources are everything. She had to make a sacrifice to protect her fledgling country, but it was worth it.
I remember that, whenever I need a bit of courage. I have her name to live up to. This blue flag, on my belt... it's from that original Enterprise.
How many ships have been given your name?
Many, Captain! The first Enterprise, a schooner, or sloop-of-war, built in 1775, and then the...

Fields.MenuText: I think your predecessors would be honored you know so much about them.
I didn't realize you were interested in naval history.
I don't need a lecture on naval history.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Captain. I do my best to honor their memory.
It's fascinating stuff! I started looking just into my predecessors, but you can learn a lot from old world navy affairs.
... It's my heritage, you know! You don't have to be so rude.
Captain! It looks like we'll have to protect the beauty of these coasts. There's a small fleet of Morganas approaching!
The brass did warn us to be wary of engaging directly...
Blow them! There are shipyards nearby, not to mention all the towns along the coast that would be easing pickings for a Morgana! We have to chase them off.
You're right.
@BATTLE
Our planes have been unstoppable lately! I'll bet our pilots could outfly any wreck the Morganas can get into the air!
The crew has been performing well, too.
I knew they would. Truly, the real combat probably helped the most, but practice never hurts.
I think they're becoming fond of you.
Ha! ...Really? Well... well, most crews I've had hadn't had many complaints. I'm shipshape and respond well to any challenge.
Have you heard what they've been calling you? The Big E.
... Hah, yes, actually! It's not a new name; I've been called it before. It's an obvious nickname, but a funny one, don't you think?

Fields.MenuText: It is. I like it.
It's a rather undignified nickname for a ship.
It's not very imaginative.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad! It would be a bit strange to call me that to my face, though!
It's good for crew to refer to their ship affectionately! It means this ship is becoming a home to them.
Hah, to be fair, neither is my name! But it is important.
You're free to nickname me as you please, Captain. So long as it isn't stupid!
I'll keep it in mind. For now, I think we have a chance to put our crew's skills to the test.
We've received communications about a small Morgana group that has been giving ports up in New York some trouble.
A chase! I'm glad they're finally trusting us to hold our own, Captain. We've certainly shown them we can lick a Morgana or three.
@BATTLE
I've seen that look. What's wrong, Captain?
These past few days, I think I've seen you working every single job on the ship, Enterprise.
I strive to live up to my name, Captain! And there's always someone who needs an extra hand.
Do you even sleep?
What use would I have for racking out? I'm a Belle! Do engines sleep? Does the sea sleep? I don't sleep anymore than you burn coal!
Really? Well, that would explain a few things. You certainly eat, though. Sometimes I think you'll single-handedly eat through our stocks.
Captain! I definitely only take my share. But eating is different. A girl can't live on coal and sea spray alone. It's sleep I can go without.

Fields.MenuText: That's handy. I wish I could go without it.
Fair enough.
Sleep is very necessary for most of us.

Fields.DialogueText: Alas, the bounds of humanity, hmm? Ha, but there are advantages to being like you, Captain.
Am I annoying you, Captain?
I understand, Captain. It's part of what makes me useful, I guess.
I don't think you'll be turning in any time soon, Captain... my RDF just picked up bogeys. Probably Morganas.
I suppose Morganas probably don't need much rest either.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
We're almost in range, Captain!
Steady on.
Oh, I'm steady. No worries there!
@BATTLE
Captain! Could you help me find the cats? I can't find them after that fight... I think that last shell spooked them.

Fields.MenuText: It spooked me. That was much too close a call for comfort.
I'd expect ship's cats to be made of stronger stuff.
They'll have to get used to it.

Fields.DialogueText: Chin up, Captain, we came out of it fine!
They're still young ship's cats. They're still getting their sea legs!
Don't worry. They'll quickly be dodging shells as cavalierly as any veteran seaman.
Why do you need to find them, anyway?
I wanted to make sure they were all well. One of the nurses sewed them these cute little collars, and it makes them easier to spot. Will you help me with the hunt, Cap?
There are many, many matters I have to attend to, Enterprise. That shell might not have hurt us, but we lost good men and women today.
... I know, Captain.
You're not acting like it.
... It will be easier to think about later. When we have the funerals, and when... when I speak.
I just... I just can't do anything right now. I can't fix anything, I can't help them. I want to, but I can't. I can help the cats. Please, will you help me find them?
... Very well. For a bit.
Why have we altered course, Captain?
We just received word from the Fleet. The US Naval base and the shipyard in Newport News were hit by several Morganas.
Damn! Is... did they fight them off?!
Yes, they managed to repel them, but just barely. The base's armaments were badly damaged, and they're vulnerable to further attack.
Are we being sent to defend them?
Eventually, but first we've been ordered to chase after the fleeing ships and make sure they don't think of turning back around. Think we can handle it?
Absolutely, Captain. We have to.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Don't get tunnel vision. We swat them down and await further orders.
We'll make them pay, Enterprise. Don't you worry.
The mainland will be fine, Enterprise. They've got us.

Fields.DialogueText: You know, I've never boiled an ocean before.
I'm washing my mouth out with soap, Captain. Gotta save up some choice curses for those hags.
They better be. All the work we get up to... I'd never forgive them if they went and died on us!
Captain, my senses... are those them?
That's a smaller battle group than reported. Must be stragglers.
Ooh, I know exactly what to do with those!
Captain! Look! There on the horizon! It's...
Another aircraft carrier. Sin.
She's on a course to Newport News! We've got to stop her!
... Here we go again.
@BATTLE
Augh... we got her... Captain...
At what cost? That last volley shook the whole ship!
A... lucky parting shot. But I'm fine. We've got to make it back to Newport News. I'm worried about the shipyard.
We're in no condition to go anywhere.
My engines weren't badly damaged. I'm still capable of limping along. Come on, we have to...
And what if you are not as lucky next battle? I won't risk you sinking...
I won't! My compartmentalized hull makes me a hard ship to sink, Captain. I know what I'm capable of handling far better than you.

Fields.MenuText: You may, but the fact is we're in no condition to go anywhere quickly.
Your arrogance could get all of us killed.
You're being insubordinate to your captain?

Fields.DialogueText: I... I know I can make it, Captain. Maybe not quickly, but this ship can still move.
It won't! We're a sitting duck out here anyway, a target! If we make it back to the shipyard, we'll be safer as well!
I'm not being insubordinate! I'm... I'm not! I'm just telling you what I think, and I'm right in this instance!
This conversation is going in circles.
The Brits have a battleship that saved its sister by going in circles! Don't knock an eagle just because it flies crooked.
You look like hell.
... I just got back from there. I've been down in the hold, helping with repairs.
... How many crew did we lose? In the fight with Sin?
Too many. And we could've lost you, too.
I won't sink, Captain. Why won't you listen to me, believe me on that?

Fields.MenuText: You tend to push yourself too much, Enterprise.
You seem to want to put yourself in harm's way, sometimes.
Because you seem to have a damn death wish, that's why!

Fields.DialogueText: I don't, Captain! There weren't any other capable ships nearby, not to mention Belles. We were the shipyard's only hope of defense!
I don't want to put myself in harm's way, but I'm not backing down when my home is in danger!
You don't know what you're talking about! Would you prefer we left the shipyard to be destroyed?
Would you rather have a Belle who stepped aside and let her countrymen die to preserve her own safety?
Would you rather we let the Morganas gobble up the resources in Newport News and lay the rest to waste?
Some of your countrymen, and more of your crew, are dead because of our actions, Enterprise.
... I regret that. But that's all of our lot in this life, isn't it? We're supposed to be ready to sacrifice for the safety of others. It's important.
... That's true. I don't regret fighting Sin, or the others. We won. But not by much. We can't charge so recklessly into fights like that anymore, or you'll sink, and we'll die.
Preaching to the choir, Captain.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Captain? Come look at this!
What is it, Enterprise?
Come look! Cap's got herself stuck on top of your cabin!
... That's a ginger kitten. And Cap? You named the ginger kitten after me?
Yep!
I'm not sure whether to be flattered or insulted.
Listen, Captain... I'm sorry for my behavior, earlier. I'm sorry for being insubordinate, and stubborn. I'm sorry for putting you and the crew at risk.

Fields.MenuText: You're forgiven, Enterprise. We had to fight them, one way or another.
We had to fight them, one way or another. In the end, your attitude didn't matter.
I don't know that I can forgive you quite yet, Enterprise.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you. I know, but I also got carried away.
It did matter, though. I was treating the situation recklessly.
... I understand. I was treating your life flippantly. The lives of the crew, too.
I just wanted to protect my home. It turns out I wasn't quite strong enough for it.
Don't talk like that. We did a fine job. Not a perfect one, but the best we could, given the circumstances.
If we're going to get ourselves in that sort of situation again, we need to be better prepared.
I know, Captain. I have some ideas... next time, we'll be better prepared. I'll be better prepared.
My RDF just picked up something heading this way, Captain. I think we should be prepared for another fight.
Damn. I was hoping the Morganas would think us sunk, and leave us alone to make repairs.
@BATTLE
Ever hunt a deer, Captain? Even when they're downed, you'd be surprised how they can thrash...
I'm excited to meet our new passenger, Captain! What do you know of her?
Her name is Miss Kumar - she's from India originally, but has been working in a shipyard in Boston, helping design new defenses against the Morganas' weapons.
I heard she works for the Fleet?
She does - they loan her to helpful shipyards. They want her in Newport News, since a good number of engineers were killed or injured in the attack.
That seems sensible. I'd like to talk to her about possible improvements to the ship. I can stand up to a lot, but those torpedoes...

Fields.MenuText: Well, like you said, you didn't sink. That's a decent idea, though, if she has time.

Fields.DialogueText: We'll be in New York shortly. I can see the coastline from here... Captain! Look!
Damn Morganas. They seem to be going after the American coastline more frequently than normal. I wonder why...?
Their reasons don't matter now. Call all hands to stations!
@BATTLE
She'll have time for me, Captain. Even an egghead wouldn't pass up an opportunity to meet one of us!

Fields.MenuText: She's got important work to do. Don't distract her.

Fields.DialogueText: What kind of ship would I be if I didn't roll out the red carpet?

Fields.MenuText: She might just save us all from ourselves.

Fields.DialogueText: We're in this together, Captain. I wouldn't have picked you if you didn't have a little piss and vinegar.
I still can't believe the things you survive.
Start believing, Captain. I could get really reckless if she'd whip up some heavier armor...
Enterprise, I was just wondering... oh. Sorry. I didn't mean to interrupt your... reading?
Don't look so surprised, Captain! I read!
I just haven't seen you so absorbed before, unless it was one of those books about your predecessors. Did you bribe one of my officers to buy you another one?
No, Captain. It's not even a history... it's a play. Shakespeare's Othello. I borrowed it from Miss Kumar.

Fields.MenuText: I've read the play before. It's interesting. Rather profound.
I've read it. It's rubbish.
I've never read it before.

Fields.DialogueText: Hmm. I'm almost finished with it. It is interesting, but rather dark.
Hah, I can see why you'd think so. It's interesting, but a bit melodramatic, to be honest.
It's pretty good, as plays go, but a bit dark and depressing. Not exactly the thing to cheer you up after a rough day.
What's got you so interested in it, then?
They used a quote from it at my christening. I remember it well... the ocean was cold and gray, and the wind was brisk, and the speaker said...
May she also say with just pride: I have done the State some service.
That seems a noble sort of quote.
I've always thought so! It... had an effect on me, you know. It's one of my earliest memories. But... well, in context, it's not so noble... sigh.
Maybe they didn't read the play before choosing the quote.
Ha! That's probably true. Lots of people like to say they've read Shakespeare! Anyway, it was a fine way to waste an afternoon, but I'm itching for some action.
Well, you've got your wish. We've been cautiously ordered to go after a Morgana group targeting shipping lines off Maine.
Pirate Morganas to hunt? I'm a girl of simple tastes, Captain, and you know just how to brighten my day.
@BATTLE
Wait...I think I feel them now!
I'm no strategist, Captain, but with the number of Morgana attacks recently focused on the American coast, it seems the Morganas are after industry.
I mean, that's one of the prides of my country. Probably our main contribution to the war effort!
We can outproduce any other nation, so the Morganas must view us as a threat.
The Fleet has come to the same conclusion. That's why we're still on cruise up and down the coast. They're happy with the efforts we've made in defending it so far...
I'm sensing a "but" rearing its ugly little head.
Mmm, well, given the amount of damage you took last time we fought off a large attack, and the fact that Newport News was so badly damaged...
... they're considering a battleship or two in our place.
That would be stupid of them! There's no Belle who knows this coast better than me... aside from my sister ship, I suppose. And a few other American Belles.

Fields.MenuText: We can't guard the coast forever, Enterprise. If the Fleet thinks we'd be more useful elsewhere...

Fields.DialogueText: I'd love the chance to explore new waters, Captain, but I think the Fleet would be wrong to reassign us now.
Well...
We'll have to put this discussion on hold, Captain. My instruments just picked up a Morgana lurking nearby.
@BATTLE
Look at that Morgana run, tail between her legs, smoke pouring out of every porthole! Who needs heavy artillery when you've got aircraft like ours?
The pilots did perform admirably.
Our aircraft can protect the coast far better than any battleship's artillery. I concede, my hull is too fragile... but Miss Kumar is working on arranging a solution for that.
I've heard about that. We'll have to see if it all works out.

Fields.MenuText: My hands are tied, Enterprise.

Fields.DialogueText: A few smoking Morgana hulks ought to untie 'em.

Fields.MenuText: I've been telling them that, believe me.

Fields.DialogueText: I fight a hell of a lot harder knowing you're going to bat for me. Some of those stuffed shirts still don't see the girl for the girders...
Rolling home, rolling hooome... Oh! Damn, you startled me, Captain.
I can see you've got your whole litter here. Do all the cats have names yet?
Mhmm. This is the proud momma, Lu, and Rose, Six, and Cap.
Cap...
Are you still angry that I named the kitten after you?

Fields.MenuText: Nah. I know it's because I'm clever as a cat.
Nah. I know it's because she's just as pretty as I am.
Out of all the names you could have chosen, it had to be mine?

Fields.DialogueText: And just as conceited! But she does have that same mischievous sparkle in her eye, doesn't she?
And just as pleased with herself, too. But she is a little dandy, just like you.
I just like your name. You're my captain, after all.
Hmm. You're flattering me.
I'm no good at flattery. Rude am I in my speech, and little blessed with the soft phrase of peace.
Shakespeare.
Othello. It's growing on me! I'm glad Miss Kumar lent it to me... but speaking of her, I have a feeling the Morganas may not want her to reach Virginia.
There's another pack of them tailing us.
We've lost enough time as it is. We'll try to outrun them.
I hate running. It wouldn't take long to blow them out of the water.
It wouldn't be the right decision now, Enterprise. Trust me.
I don't think we get to make it, Cap...
@BATTLE
Have you seen Miss Kumar's diagrams of the torpedo blister to fit to my hull? The Morganas' torpedoes would have a tough time getting anywhere with that installed.
It looks promising. I'm hoping the Fleet will be willing to pay for the expense, given our recent exploits.
They had better! It's common sense. You don't want an investment like me to be sunk by a couple cheap torpedoes.
Like you've pointed out, you weren't in much danger of sinking.
Semantics! And you certainly weren't so sure of that at the time.
I didn't know you or your capabilities so well. What captain wouldn't be alarmed when their ship had a massive hole blown in the side?
Point taken. I do have some pull in Newport News, Captain.
If you give me a bit of time on the docks once we reach the port, I might be able to get the cost of my refitting a bit reduced.

Fields.MenuText: That would make the Fleet more likely to approve the refitting, certainly.
Do what you like. Just make sure not to step on any toes.
I'm not sure I care to trust you on any mission of diplomacy.

Fields.DialogueText: Put the navies of the world together and you get a bunch of cheapskates. Who knew?
I'll be the soul of discretion, Captain. I promise!
This is my hometown, Captain. I have the home field advantage.
Very well. Do what you can.
On it, Captain. I think those Morganas we whipped before aren't taking the hint...
@BATTLE
Leaving Newport News like this again is giving me déjà vu. I think I've been scrubbed as clean as I was when I was christened. Almost feels like nothing has changed.
Except you awoke, and chose me as your captain.
Of course. Did you ever think you'd be standing on my bridge?

Fields.MenuText: Of course. It was my goal, for one day.
Maybe not you specifically, but I've always dreamt of a captain's commission.
Truthfully, no. I didn't believe I'd ever make captain.

Fields.DialogueText: I respect that ambition! I'm glad I was able to help you accomplish that goal.
That's a worthwhile ambition. I'm glad you agreed to become my captain.
Ah, you underestimated yourself! You shouldn't do that, Captain. Always push yourself further. It's the only way we can accomplish the extraordinary.
I'm glad I chose you as my captain.
I'm glad you chose me, too. But you also have your new torpedo blister. How's that feeling?
It's an adjustment, but I'm eager to test it out and cut my teeth on some Morganas. The crew has had too much downtime during my refitting!
You're in luck. From the sounds of it, the lookout just spotted something.
Morganas! This close to Newport News? Again?!
@BATTLE
The Morganas are definitely targeting American shipyards, Captain. Newport News should be able to defend themselves once the naval base is fully repaired...
But not all shipyards are so heavily guarded.
All the shipyards' defenses should be reworked, and beefed up to be able to contend with a coordinated attack by the Morganas.
I wonder why they're so intent on the shipyards. To prevent our ships from being assembled and refitted, of course.
That could be reason enough!
But like you suggested before, they may need the resources too.
That's true. Too bad we haven't had any luck capturing them... I'd bet I could get answers out of one of those rats.

Fields.MenuText: Any Morgana would find it hard to stand up to your enthusiasm.
You have some capacity to be threatening.
What would you do - threaten them with your toy airplanes?

Fields.DialogueText: I doubt she would react any better than a Belle to her ship being taken apart in front of her.
More than just some capacity, Captain! You underestimate me.
Don't mock my models, Captain! My hobbies have nothing to do with my ability to destroy Morganas.
Regardless, we're unlikely to get our hands on one to ask questions to, so we'll have to settle with chasing them off as best we can.
Speaking of which, my RDF is picking up another one approaching us. Are you ready for a fight?
Always.
@BATTLE
Captain! There's a fleet of Morganas heading towards Brooklyn! I think they're going to attack the Brooklyn Navy Yard!
How many are your instruments picking up?
I'm getting interference, so it's hard to be sure. We're the only Neutrality Fleet vessel within close range.
I think we can handle them.
Of course we can! Tis in ourselves that we are thus or thus!

Fields.MenuText: I'm not sure I appreciate Miss Kumar lending you that play.

Fields.DialogueText: @BATTLE
Ha! Fool me once, but you shouldn't try the same tricks again, Morganas!
I don't think they were expecting an aircraft carrier. Probably thought they sunk you before.
I'm the scariest ghost they'll ever meet, then!

Fields.MenuText: More Othello?

Fields.DialogueText: That Shakespeare gent really had a way with words! You ought to try him out.
I can't strafe a Morgana with it, but it'll have to do!

Fields.MenuText: Didn't the villain say that?

Fields.DialogueText: You can learn a thing or two from the bad guys. Just ask Kumar!
The new torpedo blister has served us well so far, Enterprise.
I'm glad. Just another example of the fine work of the boys at Newport News... and Miss Kumar's design, of course.
The brass at Brooklyn Navy Yard sounded incredibly grateful in their communications. They said they were prepared for a single ship attacking, but not three at once.
I think they'll be thanking us again shortly. Look! To starboard! That's Sin and company!

Fields.MenuText: She just won't leave us alone, will she?

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe she meant to come to the rescue of her smaller sisters. Too late! We'll have to show her the price of being slow.
Just don't scare the cats, eh?

Fields.MenuText: Think you can take her?

Fields.DialogueText: No choice, Captain! Get through us and they get through Brooklyn.

Fields.MenuText: There's still time to disengage if necessary.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't know the meaning of the word!
We're damn lucky they found her.
Luck ain't got nothing to do with it, Captain. These are crazy times. You have to be exceptional to step up, and you have to be amazing to survive when you do.
Ha! I like a challenge, Captain, but you don't serve aboard me without giving fear a good hiding.
They're certainly adept at hiding.
Watch the puns, Captain, or you've got a one-way ticket to Morgana town!
@BATTLE
New York is so beautiful, from out in the water... it glows from miles away.
It's not all that beautiful close up, you know.
I think it is. All those people... all those voices... the industry, the busy-ness of it all... it's beautiful. It's dirty, and rough, and dangerous, but it's worth protecting.
Is it as beautiful as Virginia?
Ha! It doesn't hold a candle to Virginia, but few places do.
We have new orders.
Oh? Really? Exciting! It will be good to set out on a new cruise.
Really? You won't mind leaving the American coast bereft of your guardianship?
Not at all. We've taught the Morganas a lesson, I think, and the shipyards are working to increase their defenses.
I love this coast, but there are other places to defend. It will be good to stretch my wings.
You won't be stretching them too far. We're heading down to South America, to your old haunts.
Excellent! I haven't had good feijoada in years!

Fields.MenuText: You'll have to be my food guide while we're there.
Perhaps we could have a nice dinner while we're there?

Fields.DialogueText: You know I'd be happy to do so, Captain!
I'm always up for a nice dinner, Captain. Especially with you.
Steady, Enterprise! We'll eat like kings in Brooklyn tonight!
Recruit owes me one for this!
@BATTLE
